citing_paper_authors: Zhi, Zhong | Hwee Tou, Ng
raw_text: As a fundamental task in natural language processing (NLP), WSDcan benefit applications such as machine translation (Chan et al, 2007a; Carpuat and Wu, 2007) and information retrieval (Stokoe et al, 2003)

citing_paper_authors: Rada, Mihalcea | Ravi, Sinha | Diana, McCarthy
raw_text: Unlike a full blown machine translation task (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), annotators and systems are not required to translate the whole context but just the target word
clean_text: Unlike a full blown machine translation task (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), annotators and systems are not required to translate the whole context but just the target word.

citing_paper_authors: Douwe, Gelling | Trevor, Cohn
raw_text: (Carpuat and Wu, 2007) report an improvement in translation quality by incorporating a WSD system directly in a phrase-based translation system. This is in response to earlier work done, where in corp orating the output of a traditional WSD system gave disappointing results (Carpuat and Wu, 2005)
clean_text: (Carpuat and Wu, 2007) report an improvement in translation quality by incorporating a WSD system directly in a phrase-based translation system.

citing_paper_authors: Douwe, Gelling | Trevor, Cohn
raw_text: This system is trained on the same data as the SMT system is. The output of this model is incorporated into the machine translation system by providing the WSD probabilities for a phrase translation as extra features in a log-linear model (Carpuat and Wu, 2007)
clean_text: The output of this model is incorporated into the machine translation system by providing the WSD probabilities for a phrase translation as extra features in a log-linear model (Carpuat and Wu, 2007).

citing_paper_authors: Douwe, Gelling | Trevor, Cohn
raw_text: However, the way the system is set up, it could also be viewed as a way of incorporating translation probabilities of other systems into the phrase-based translation model. (Chan and Ng, 2007) introduce a system very similar to that of (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), but asap plied to hierarchical phrase-based translation
clean_text: (Chan and Ng, 2007) introduce a system very similar to that of (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), but as applied to hierarchical phrase-based translation.

clean_text: Another WSD approach incorporating context-dependent phrasal translation lexicons is given in (Carpuatand Wu, 2007) and has been evaluated on several translation tasks.

raw_text: Second, instead of disambiguating phrase senses as in (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), we model word selection independently of the phrases used in the MT models
clean_text: Second, instead of disambiguating phrase senses as in (Carpuat and Wu, 2007), we model word selection independently of the phrases used in the MT models.

citing_paper_authors: Eleftherios, Avramidis | Philipp, Koehn
raw_text: Carpuat and Wu (2007) approached the issue as a Word Sense Disambiguation problem. In their presentation of the factored SMT mod els, Koehn and Hoang (2007) describe experiments for translating from English to German, Spanish and Czech, using morphology tags added on the morphologically rich side, along with POS tags
clean_text: Carpuat and Wu (2007) approached the issue as a Word Sense Disambiguation problem.

citing_paper_authors: Jan, Niehues | Teresa, Herrmann | Stephan, Vogel | Alex, Waibel
raw_text: In Chan and Ng (2007) a classifier exploits information such as local col locations, parts-of-speech or surrounding words to determine the lexical choice of target words, while Carpuat and Wu (2007) use rich context features based on position, syntax and local collocations to dynamically adapt the lexicons for each sentence and facilitate the choice of longer phrases
clean_text: In Chan and Ng (2007) a classifier exploits information such as local collocations, parts-of-speech or surrounding words to determine the lexical choice of target words, while Carpuat and Wu (2007) use rich context features based on position, syntax and local collocations to dynamically adapt the lexicons for each sentence and facilitate the choice of longer phrases.

raw_text: In Carpuat and Wu (2007), another state-of-the-art WSD engine (a combination of naive Bayes, maximum entropy, boosting and Kernel PCA models) is used to dynamically determine the score of a phrase pair under cons id eration and, thus, let the phrase selection adapt to the context of the sentence
clean_text: In Carpuat and Wu (2007), another state-of-the-art WSD engine (a combination of naive Bayes, maximum entropy, boosting and Kernel PCA models) is used to dynamically determine the score of a phrase pair under consideration and, thus, let the phrase selection adapt to the context of the sentence.

citing_paper_authors: Roberto, Navigli | Simone Paolo, Ponzetto
raw_text: The key insight here is that Word Sense Disambiguation and Machine Translation (MT) are highly intertwined tasks, as previously shown by Carpuat and Wu (2007) and Chan et al (2007), who successfully used sense information to boost state-of-the-art statistical MT. In this work we focus instead on the benefits of using multilingual information for WSD by exploiting the structure of a multilingual semantic network
clean_text: The key insight here is that Word Sense Disambiguation and Machine Translation (MT) are highly intertwined tasks, as previously shown by Carpuat and Wu (2007) and Chan et al (2007), who successfully used sense information to boost state-of-the-art statistical MT.

clean_text: Carpuat and Wu (2007a, 2007b) and Chan et al (2007) have integrated word sense disambiguation (WSD) and phrase sense disambiguation (PSD) into SMT systems.

citing_paper_authors: Boxing, Chen | George, Foster | Roland, Kuhn
raw_text: Key papers by Carpuat and Wu (2007) and Chan et al (2007) showed that word-sense disambiguation (WSD) techniques relying on source-language context can be effective in selecting translations in phrase-based and hierarchical SMT
clean_text: Key papers by Carpuat and Wu (2007) and Chan et al (2007) showed that word-sense disambiguation (WSD) techniques relying on source-language context can be effective in selecting translations in phrase-based and hierarchical SMT.
